59ECAACC936649CD94BE5B5A611DC40C.description: outline the role of the governing agencies in monitoring and establishing guidelines based on the spread of infectious diseases.

CDEA0CAF6B1E49CABA9226541B515C1F.description: investigate drug-resistant microorganisms such as carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, vancomycin-intermediate/resistant Staphylococci aureus, vancomycin-resistant enterococci, and emergent antibiotic-resistant superbugs; and

14ED0FE3F35C4F6187F29E50CDC31769.description: identify common bacterial infections from hospital-acquired infection and community-acquired infections such as Clostridium difficile and Staphylococcus aureus;

A031A22177DF496DAA6B86129DBEB088.description: examine reemergence of diseases such as malaria, tuberculosis, and polio;

D5AB9D0DBDCB4806AAA1A8A258B8A4B9.description: evaluate the effects of anti-microbial agents such as narrow and broad spectrum antibiotics;

05D54C4F7CF943DA94080754D8E250B9.description: explain the body's immune response and defenses against infection;

4661A5A1E58B4CDE9476A7B907FF76B8.description: categorize diseases caused by bacteria, fungi, viruses, protozoa, rickettsias, arthropods, and helminths;

0E90D51B7E3E44D9B0F2265BB0BB99FC.description: outline the infectious process, including how pathogenic microorganisms affect human body systems;

14236B5B3DAB41A89CE400B6BF8AF7E8.description: The student examines the role of microorganisms in infectious diseases. The student is expected to:

7BC6E4E5EA994F1F9C2DDDFCFA24E61E.description: explain the role of the sensitivity report provided to the clinician by the microbiology department.

BAB35A499B2848A4A0E21598E79D69D5.description: discuss the results of laboratory procedures such as biochemical reactions that are used to identify microorganisms; and

F76591B487F24AAFB42AD327FCA588E8.description: describe the colony morphology of microorganisms;

1FCD5082DB8B43E29CD98ABF52584546.description: distinguish between pathogens, opportunistic pathogens, hospital-acquired infections, and colonizing microorganisms;

2B91F582CD5445DDA0A29B08F237ABA5.description: identify the normal flora microorganisms of the human body;

B80471A60C854A65A9D3937C2B9B701D.description: recognize the factors required for microbial reproduction and growth;

2C9177B1C39241A1A8D55C3F0F7C9A30.description: explain the difference between Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria regarding the bacterial cell wall;

2B436D7B545545D7B5C47E756D5562C4.description: classify microorganisms using a dichotomous key;

22786BF4F631432DB524DBFBC8023779.description: The student is expected to perform and analyze results in the microbiology laboratory. The student is expected to:

D3E352997ED541FFB9ACB315F3EB0185.description: research roles, functions, and responsibilities of agencies governing infectious disease control.

805C638311DD48E68CBDFC16A1FB5646.description: research and describe the historical development of microbiology as it relates to health care of an individual; and

5D9D42D164D64D97A7441A8C22A7EC38.description: The student describes the relationships between microorganisms and health and wellness in the human body. The student is expected to:

A9F18893038A4872AFC9587E666D6D6F.description: research and describe the history of science and contributions of scientists.

19AE11B3CB3C472693DCEB41540858FA.description: evaluate models according to their limitations in representing biological objects or events; and

EEE6E72900C84965BAE2DD1FFC4C5ACE.description: evaluate the impact of scientific research on society and the environment;

BFDB1F0FA03048588BA515E255D6AEAA.description: draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services;

5534D8BC09304F829C8B3E25D3C9C7C4.description: communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as accredited scientific journals, institutions of higher learning, current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

788E79A175FD4DE7BDF85D4F268BA5F7.description: in all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking

0C7A94BADC40468DA0E3895B215D4B96.description: The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom. The student is expected to:

643FAA835062409198EB0B4D337730FD.description: employ standard precautions, including proper protective equipment during all laboratory exercises.

CDA0F8983D5C4BD6B7B61A63C1E5E66B.description: dispose of all biological material in the proper biohazard containers; and

D2347AF7FC52429A9C02FCC806449514.description: communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports;

C2F4DD92BC344B38B0251BC298B95733.description: analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data;

B7ADA7C924FA4562BCFBAC3CCCB094F5.description: collect and organize qualitative and quantitative data and make measurements with accuracy and precision using tools such as calculators, spreadsheet software, data-collecting probes, computers, standard laboratory glassware, microscopes, various prepared slides, stereoscopes, metric rulers, electronic balances, gel electrophoresis apparatuses, micropipettors, hand lenses, Celsius thermometers, hot plates, lab notebooks or journals, timing devices, Petri dishes, lab incubators, dissection equipment, meter sticks, and models, diagrams, or samples of biological specimens or structures;

2FEDD4A8FF9844D3BAACD1813AF45FAB.description: plan and implement descriptive, comparative, and experimental investigations, including asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting equipment and technology;

4AA79D4176544F54B0C1BFB673413D38.description: distinguish between scientific hypothesis and scientific theories;

6598E079A14A436893859B769A7801A0.description: know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change as new areas of science are created and new technologies emerge;

6A4221519EAC44138517397922177762.description: know that hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power that have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories;

618518B3062B46B190311847B0BF829F.description: know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in subsection (b)(4) of this section;

291D3BB342CB4C88B19DF739279AD34E.description: The student uses scientific methods and equipment during laboratory and field investigations. The student is expected to:

77EC5C1B0A2C44A59CE838D84479A07D.description: demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

BBA06D3BD41540B99EEFFF6819BEB58B.description: demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations; and

7A15437D51D24801B6B633E51E1733B4.description: The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts field and laboratory investigations using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. These investigations must involve actively obtaining and analyzing data with physical equipment, but may also involve experimentation in a simulated environment as well as field observations that extend beyond the classroom. The student is expected to:

D1E49E74476E4EE3AF588FE9C814AC18.description: exhibit the ability to cooperate, contribute, and collaborate as a member of a team.

33E62A8C266544D3A69B7D5D4F350C3D.description: demonstrate verbal and non-verbal communication in a clear, concise, and effective manner; and

9A5FF9F467204DAF950DCB1000E9A50B.description: The student demonstrates professional standards/employability skills as required by business and industry. The student is expected to:

9814152BF09D4C6DA160CF68DBD8EBC1.description: Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

2A9B7022728442F08542EED5DB18B022.description: Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other leadership or extracurricular organizations.

AF74082E7E2C4D51BCDFF42098ADBB5C.description: A system is a collection of cycles, structures, and processes that interact. All systems have basic properties that can be described in space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested. Students should analyze a system in terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external environment.

FEBA236551DA4D3EACF69BDD71468CF9.description: Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world. Students should be able to distinguish between scientific decision-making methods (scientific methods) and ethical and social decisions that involve science (the application of scientific information).

6FC19BE7D90C47408B6E28EA2DCECB27.description: Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world. Scientific methods of investigation are experimental, descriptive, or comparative. The method chosen should be appropriate to the question being asked.

6F5E5B4362D64D55B034F3044A5E68FE.description: Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

C41C181458D8456CAF17E6D42AE0590F.description: The Medical Microbiology course is designed to explore the microbial world, studying topics such as pathogenic and non-pathogenic microorganisms, laboratory procedures, identifying microorganisms, drug resistant organisms, and emerging diseases.

B096F02CF5CA4B869C1B80035EA230B5.description: The Health Science Career Cluster focuses on planning, managing, and providing therapeutic services, diagnostic services, health informatics, support services, and biotechnology research and development.

D85781A8EE4A4A4DAF7B94586471AA72.description: Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic standards and relevant technical knowledge and skills for students to further their education and succeed in current or emerging professions.

61AA5EE645004B8FB4D50EA39CE7E8B4.description: General requirements. This course is recommended for students in Grades 10-12. Prerequisites: Biology and Chemistry. Recommended prerequisite: a course from the Health Science Career Cluster. Students must meet the 40% laboratory and fieldwork requirement. This course satisfies a high school science graduation requirement. Students shall be awarded one credit for successful completion of this course.
